title: 108_s3024
content: The "National Center for Transportation Solutions Act of 2004" establishes the National Center for Transportation Solutions and outlines its duties, organization, powers, and personnel matters. It also authorizes the creation of regional centers for transportation solutions and provides for the authorization of appropriations. Congress finds that research and development are crucial for a transportation system that meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, efficiency, equity, and environmental protection goals. Despite a 40% increase in overall transportation funding, resources for transportation research have remained stagnant. There is a need for more funding and a focus on long-term strategic research through competitive, peer-reviewed awards. The diversity of transportation research programs poses challenges in addressing the needs of different customers. The diversity of transportation research programs poses challenges in addressing the needs of different customers. To ensure the United States transportation system meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, equity, and environmental protection goals, increasing federal investment in long-range transportation planning, supporting competitive research, coordinating research programs, and fostering interchange of transportation are essential. The Department of Transportation aims to better coordinate research and development programs, foster data interchange, and establish nationwide priorities in federal transportation research and development. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is established as an independent agency in the executive branch of government. It consists of the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board and the Director of National Transportation Research. The Board will exercise the authorities of the Center. The Center's duties include coordinating research and development programs, fostering data interchange, and establishing nationwide priorities in federal transportation research and development. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is responsible for developing a long-term national policy for research and development in multimodal transportation. It initiates projects with public benefits, provides grants for strategic transportation objectives, and facilitates data interchange among interested parties in the United States. The National Center for Transportation Solutions facilitates the interchange of transportation research data among interested parties in the United States, serves as a clearinghouse of information for individuals engaged in transportation research, consults with officials from the Department of Transportation, and coordinates scientific research programs with public and private research groups. It evaluates programs related to transportation research and development conducted by the United States Government and submits an annual report to Congress with recommendations on research and development activities. The National Center for Transportation Solutions submits an annual report to Congress with recommendations on research and development related to multimodal transportation, including minority views and recommendations from board members. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established with 16 voting members, including appointments by the Secretary of Transportation, the Director of the National Academies, and the President. Members must represent various professions and sectors. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 voting members appointed by various entities. Members must represent different professions, regions, possess relevant skills, and serve staggered terms of 4 or 6 years with a limit of two consecutive terms. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members serve staggered terms of 4 or 6 years, with a limit of two consecutive terms. The term of a member does not expire during election years, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Board members must hold their initial meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Board will meet as called by the Chair, with a majority of members forming a quorum. The Board will select a Chairman and Vice Chairman from its members, serving 2-year terms with a limit of two consecutive terms as Chairman. The Director of National Transportation Research, appointed by the President with Senate consent, serves as the chief executive of the Center, carries out its powers, and is a nonvoting member of the Board. The Director's term is six years, with a salary capped at the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Center's organization is outlined in Section 7. The Center is organized into divisions including Transportation Safety, Environmental Planning, Infrastructure, Intermodal Connections, and Transportation Economics. Each division has a committee composed of at least five members serving two-year terms and electing a Chairman annually. Each division committee elects a Chairman annually and sets its own procedures within Board restrictions. The Center has powers as outlined in Section 8. The Board and division committees have the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, enter into contracts, and use postal services to carry out the purposes of the Act. They may also secure information directly from federal departments or agencies as needed. The Board and division committees have the authority to accept gifts, publish research results, and dispose of donations. SEC. 9. CENTER PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Director has the authority to appoint and dismiss staff for the Center without following civil service laws. The staff's responsibilities include creating strategic and annual plans, developing budgets, overseeing programs and grants, providing support to the Board, and reporting on program progress. Coordination with personnel from other departments is also required. The Director has the authority to appoint and dismiss staff for the Center without following civil service laws. Center personnel compensation can be fixed by the Director. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Center without reimbursement. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured. The Director has the authority to appoint and dismiss staff for the Center without following civil service laws. Center personnel compensation can be fixed by the Director. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured at specified rates. Volunteer services can be accepted without certain restrictions. SEC. 10. REGIONAL CENTERS FOR TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS. The Director will award grants to establish regional centers for transportation solutions in four regions of the United States. These centers will conduct research on long-term multimodal transportation issues with clear public benefits. The northeast regional center will be located in one of the top 5 states with high traffic congestion on National Highway System roads. The United States measures traffic congestion based on the ratio of annual vehicle miles traveled on National Highway System roads to the number of lane miles in each state. States with high congestion levels are determined by the ratio of urban road miles to urban lane miles. Authorization of appropriations from the Highway Trust Fund for fiscal years 2006 to 2010: $50,000,000 in 2006, $100,000,000 in 2007, $150,000,000 in 2008, $200,000,000 in 2009, and $250,000,000 in 2010.
